comments.text:
+AnHRTBus dude, these cars aren't 1980s ferraris^^
these cars are so good by now that you don't need that much of a control 
check.... except you really just do 1000km with them in a year^^ but i 
actually study car engineering in wolfsburg and already saw veyrons with 
quite many km for a supercar (most was almost 150kkm - about 90k miles)^^
no need to explain, already saw a veyron engine live^^ and as said... 
studying car engineering in wolfsburg (ostfalia university of applied 
sciences... our facility is about 400m away from the VW factory, so you see 
quite a lot vw stuff already xD plus the veyron parts are produced in 
slazgitter - less than 30 miles away from here)
well... they also could've gone with the normal 60° angle for W16 
engines... that the outer 2 banks would look like a porsche boxer, but yes 
the VR basis is very place-saving :)
but though just to tell you: very well explained, good job (Y) :D

comments.author: AnHRTBus

comments.text:
+s jep the transmission (to be exact, the whole engine) had a 4 day full 
throttle run with hours of running in the redline, hours of virtual launch 
control and racetrack testing to be qure that nothing will ever run down...
to the koenigsegg: yes... if they would fit in :)
but at a certain point it's just dangerous and not even fun anymore to have 
more hp and be faster... loeb said in the porsche 918 6:57 nordschleife run 
that it begins to stop making fun and it's more like frightening - and this 
guy is already a racedriver ^^
i think the veyron and agera are really good where they are standing now :)
comments.author: CrimnlBT

comments.text:
+CrimnlBT yes, 1000 miles. and by "servicing" i inferred to the standard 
servicing every supercar should receive every thousand miles, which is an 
oil viscosity check, tire balance and rotation (not that worrisome on a all 
wheel drive vehicle like the veyron, unless you do standing starts alot) 
and the loping transmission is an issue that happens to alot of the VW 
DSG's after a few thousand hard miles on them, not just the veyron 
specifically. and bugatti went sent a team with the top gear production 
team to check the vehicle's ECU every time they stopped for gas. But this 
is nothing new, since most of the supercar manufacturers send a support 
team with the car to top gear (McLaren and Lamborghini being the latest, 
with the P1 and Veveno roadster) 
yeah, there was supposed to be a 1 in front of that 2 to make it the 
correct 12 minutes, but my 1 key sticks and i type fast (i blame brazzers 
for that sticky key). lol
the VR part of the what im going to call from now on VRW16, refers to the 
angle of the cylinders. most variants of the VR have a very narrow (between 
10 to 15 degress) angle, and uses one cylinder head for both sets. it's 
easy to see why bugatti went with this engine design, 1, because it's a 
proprietary owned by VW, and 2, its very space saving, which allowed them 
to mount the engine(s) side by side, which opened the door for the VRW16. 
otherwise i have no trouble believing the veyron would have been 10 ft wide 
in the back if it had used a standard angled V8s to make the W16. and 
though its called a "double-u sixteen" it's actually closer to a \X/16 in 
cylinder shape, with a crossover between the two cam sets; which leaves you 
with 2 headers, each providing for one set of cylinders on each engine. and 
yes, they said that theoretically it can produce 2000 hp, but the car would 
be mainly engine and radiators, and very little car, so they "spread the 
load over 16 cylinders, which increases reliability".
comments.author: AnHRTBus

comments.text:
+CrimnlBT That's interesting wow. I bet that bugattis transmission is 
insane. imagine what koenigsegg could do with 16 cylinders or even 12
comments.author: s

comments.text:
+s i live in wolfsburg, the parts for the veyron are produced in 
salzgitter, which is just 40km away from my house^^ adding 200hp was not 
really the problem, they only had to increase the turbo size and fitted the 
engine-computer-control to do that. that breeded the next problem finding a 
clutch that can hold 1500nm. after they've done that, they improved the 
aerodynamics (obviously... compare the veyron with the ss and youll see^^).
the bugatti doesn't need the 16 cylinder engine to produce that amount of 
power, they just chose to do so because then you have less force on all 
engine parts... or said otherwise:
if you tune a koenigsegg engine to blow at 1000km, it would end up at about 
2000hp, if you tune a veyron to blow at 1000km, you end up with about 
3000hp due to more engine size, about the same materials (some parts even 
better) and shorter pistons per cylinder.
comments.author: CrimnlBT

comments.text:
+CrimnlBT I was agreeing that the Buggatti would be reliable, but only 
giving the reason that it's because of how the power produced is spread 
out, putting less strain (abrasion) on each cylinder. Where did you hear 
that Bugatti could have tuned the veyron up to 2000hp? That doesn't sound 
right considering the supersports were 200 added horsepower and it seems 
like extra things had to be done to achieve that. All I'm saying is 
Buggatti needed 16 cylinders to produce that power and koenigsegg only 
needed half of that and half the turbos and a lot less other shit. You 
don't think the agera's motor could be tuned up too? They didn't for the 
same reason as bugatti. Also it's not like both cars are running near top 
speeds at all times so wear is different at lower speeds like you said. 
The koenigsegg is a much more significant car to automotive technology and 
future tech than the Veyron which is over the top in every way. I bet even 
if the veyron is that much more reliable it still costs more in the long 
run needing to be taken care of so much.
comments.author: s

comments.text:
+AnHRTBus actually the father of an old friend of mine has a chevi 7 
seater... and it definatly uses more fuel driving 100kph than a veyron does 
when driving 180kph :P
comments.author: CrimnlBT

comments.text:
+AnHRTBus feel caressed about that "german hold forever" stuff :3
well the E85 topic is mainly a topic of making a car able to run that 
stuff... i find it cool from Königsegg to do it... but practically i can't 
use this feature normally^^
"it's still guzzling down fuel faster than any other production car in the 
world. full throttle empties the tank in 2 and a half minutes" that's just 
not true, the time is 10 minutes for the supersport and 12 for the normal 
veyron :P but actually that's not a shame... if you drive an MTM RS6 with 
730hp on the autobahn with "only" 340kph you also already use 50 liters per 
100km, man even a normal GTI or a-class needs 20 liters at full throttle 
and the supersport 120... but you are double as fast. that's just normal 
for fuel cars. actually driving 100kph all the time the veyron "only" uses 
14L which makes you go about 700km and that's actually ok.
and actually it's not even a W16, but a double VR8 engine.... some strange 
varation of V8 and golf VR6 with 16 cylinders xD
comments.author: CrimnlBT

comments.text:
+CrimnlBT but you're forgetting the cardinal rule of "less is more"
yes, bugatti made a wonderful car, but my irritation comes from idiots who 
never even heard of bugatti until they made the veyron, or until they heard 
that stupid rap song. and of course the bugatti is reliable, they're made 
by volkswagen, and those damn germans make shit that last forever if you 
care for it properly. and the agera 1000+ hp on *bio-ethanol* not E85, 
which would give you ~960 hp, meanwhile the bugatti will not run over 
200+MPH *unless* you put 91 rm+method or higher. put E85 in a veyron and 
when you hit 180 you'll start wearing seals and running lean. 
also, please note that the W16 in the veyron is not a variable sequential 
timed W16, but a interlocked W16, so no matter what, all 16 are firing 
(yes, they do work the timing down so low that it fires like a V12 untill 
full throttle, but it's still guzzling down fuel *faster than any other 
production car in the world*. full throttle empties the tank in 2 and a 
half minutes, and this is in a controlled environment, on a dyno, without 
accounting for drag and windage.) so it still looks like bugatti made a car 
more about the numbers than the driving, which is why i agree with james 
may when he says that the nurburgring ruins cars. nobody cares how fast the 
car is when it's not any fun to drive.
comments.author: AnHRTBus

top_comment.text:
We will earn respect over time. Bicycles are a fitting test to show ERW 
acceleration advantage over pneumatic tires. Motor sport will benefit by 
high frequency contact with the surface,..Just the facts...Check out our 
new Screw force acceleration vs tubeless MTB video. Never be afraid of the 
march of technology, it will happen regardless. ﻿
top_comment.author: EnergyReturnWheel

comments.text:
Bringing a carbon fiber hoop with Kevlar jacket so close to the surface. 
New traction systems are being developed. Latest published ERW patent 
addresses vacuum boost performance.
comments.author: EnergyReturnWheel

comments.text:
Surface adjustments happen between the wheel and the ground...A very short 
distance.
comments.author: EnergyReturnWheel

comments.text:
Our slow motion videos show ERW high frequency response not possible with 
pneumatic. Screw force accumulation and return adjusts each wheels rotation 
speed while maneuvering.

top_comment.author: Gilberto Rios

top_comment.text:
i think the *true* point *everyone* is missing is that this car makes over 
1,000hp (it's 1,140hp to be exact) using a *5 litre V8 with twin turbo 
chargers.*
to put that in perspective for all you secret volkswagen fans out there: 
the veyron uses a 8 litre W16 quad turbo, and makes exactly 1,001hp (for 
the standard veyron, the SS is 1,200hp)
so that is the marvel of engineering, and don't bring up the top speed 
difference, since who cares about 12 mph once you reach 200? after all, 
there are only 6 places in the world you can achieve top speeds in these 
cars, and your average buyer of any 200mph club car is never going to get 
it over 160mph.
so bugatti fanboys can stop puffing their chests, because once you break it 
down, the bugatti is a VW on steroids, wrapped in a chic exterior and 
futuristic victorian leather interior theme. it's so tech'd out it doesn't 
even really need a driver, you're just there to be there. the agera 
however, *requires* a driver, and not just any driver, one who knows *how* 
to drive.﻿
top_comment.author: AnHRTBus

comments.author: Palo Alto

comments.text:
no, it cannot be "ramped up to 3000 hp" because of the very physics you are 
talking about. the engine would slag itself before even getting near that 
amount. to make an engine able to withstand that kind of stress would 
require NASA to get in and build it with their damn rocket scientists. now, 
there are 3,000 hp piston driven engines out there, but the VRW16 the 
bugatti uses is not capable of it, for two reasons, one: they build the 
engines within the stress parameters they set. so they went out and shot 
for 1,000 hp, then they decide "ok, now what are the cheapest materials we 
can use, that are durable and reliable enough to put in a production 
vehicle?" and two: because the only other piston engines to make over 
1500hp use JP fuels, which are for aircraft. they're more stable, and have 
a higher RM+Method rating.
so "mister know it all", do me a favor and go fap somewhere else
comments.author: AnHRTBus

comments.text:
Something you should already know, mister know it all the VW engine can 
actually be ramped up too 3000HP and smother any car out there but 
something called physics and engineering made is so that the people who 
have the cash and money to spend on an expensive 3tone VW don’t burn all 
their hard earned cash on £20,000 tires just to prove a point to idiots 
like yourself. 
They are already ripping them off enough and seen as the old Veyron has the 
same 0-60 time, they limited the VW-SS to the same 0-60 time because they 
would shred their tires trying to put down any more power. Now getting more 
to the point: The Bugatti SS and Agera R are completely different cars one 
is for enthusiast who takes it out on the occasion and relishes the hard 
ride with the overwhelming sound of the engine blowing your ear drums out 
and the other for the wealthy persons who just wants to have power and 
luxury of an everyday driver that they can use at their leisure. 
PS 
I would of loved to see a standing start as well perhaps you would not be 
such a know it all and you would see that it’s really not that fast off the 
line as you might think.

comments.text:
+Stephen Bagnell Okay you have a good point but no eraser... 

GTR R35: 2013/2014: 3829 lbs
R35: VR38DETT, V6, 3.8 L, HP 545 @6,400 RPM, Max Engine Speed 7000 RPM, 
Sequential multi-point electronic fuel enjection, has 4 valves per 
cylinder, Turbocharge: Twin IHI System. 
0-60 MPH 2.72 sec (unofficial) Official is 2.84 sec
Top speed 402 KPH (250 MPH


Koenigsegg (K) 2013: dry weight 2821 lbs
0-62 @ 3.2 Secs (even with 2 mph plus it still wont go faster than r35
Estimated top speed 273 Mph (440 KMH)
engine: Aluminium V8, $ valves per cylinder with double over head camshafts
is it all wheel drive or two wheel drive..? idk
but look, The price of this thing is horrendous, although the GTR is also 
at a hig price, without even researching i know it ain't that expensive 
comparing with the Agera R
After all those specs, now look at the Transmission of both vehicles.. In a 
zig zaggy race like Bathurst (Australia this GTR will literally rape the 
Agera.. not only cause of the acceleration but also the great handling of 
AWD.. the turning circle is smaller also, not much but considering at high 
speed, it would make a big difference
Yes the Agera has 5 different types of steering modes like the F1's but in 
my oppinnion, it doesn't really make much of a difference
In a straight for over half a mile this Agera will be in front but not so 
far ahead, that GTR will be right behind it. 
And honestly... Think of the Fuel consumption.... hahahaha
I honestly would still go for a R35 GTR 
You could do so much and put so many things into it.. NISMO! :P 
with the Agera R, like.. why would you wanna ruin a beuty, and honestly i 
doubt you would be able to do much with it.. look at that engine, there 
isnt much to do
its very high maintenance at a high expense
GTR all the way.. 
But...!!! I would buy the Agera R, Sell it, then buy a GTR R35 (2014)and a 
GTR R34 (2002)

I hope i didn't come off as being rude to your reply.. just stating many 
points. haha

captions.text:
My name is Christian
von Koenigsegg.
I'm 40 years old.

And for half of my life, I've
been on the quest to be a

leader in the hypercar industry,
utilizing Swedish

design combined with visionary
technical solutions.

Our latest car, the Agera R, is
built in the old hangers of

the former Swedish fighter
jet squadron.

Their symbol, a ghost, is now
proudly painted on the back of
every Koenigsegg.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

So we're in Koenigsegg's
engine and transmission
department.

And I'm going to show a little
bit some unique details about
our transmission.

The transmission is a very
important part in order to

make the car do what it's
supposed to do, corner well,

have great traction going
forward, and also good

stability during braking
and entry in a corner.

So it might surprise some people
that the transmission

has great influence on
all of those aspects,
but it actually does.

For example, the differential
hugely influences the way the
car behaves in a corner.

In order to have great traction,
one needs to have

some sort of a differential
locking device, to make sure

that you don't get the
wheel with the least
resistance to spin.

The problem is that, if you lock
too much, the car doesn't

really want to turn, especially
if you have a
rear-wheel drive car.

So it needs to be open and
locked when needed, in order
to get maximum performance.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

So what we did, we developed
our own electronic

differential, which
sits inside here.

You can see this
black lid here.

It's manufactured here in
Skane, in Angelholm, and
designed by us.

And it incorporates a hydraulic
piston in this area,

which is pressurized by a
hydraulic line that comes here

from our gearbox management
system.

And when needed, we get the
hydraulic pressure here

pushing this piston out,
compressing the disks of the

differential that sits inside
here, giving, more or less,
lock to the differential.

This gives the possibility
to have the more open

differential mid-corner, to
reduce under-steer, give a

little bit more lock exiting the
corner, and giving a lot

of lock in the case of sudden
lift-off over-steer to
stabilize the car.

So basically, it makes
a mid-engine car
much easier to handle.

It gives it higher cornering
speeds and the possibility to

put more power down during
the exit of the corners.

So it's really instrumental to
the behavior of the whole car.
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]
[TIRES SQUEALING]
[CAR ENGINE ROARING]

Another very, very interesting
feature is at the back of this
transmission here.

Here inside we have something
we call a wet clutch.

And people might wonder what
is a wet clutch and what is

the opposite, meaning
a dry clutch.

So in the front here, between
the gearbox and engine, we
have a normal dry clutch.

And the dry clutch means that
it's just clutch plates which

are being pressed together
with spring force
that you can open.

And they're freely
spinning in air.

There is no moisture
around them.

It's just a dry environment,
pretty much.

But a wet clutch is the
clutch that is in an
environment of oil.

Basically, that's
the same thing.

But instead of being surrounded
by the normal

atmosphere or air, it's
surrounded by some type of

fluid like, in this
case, gearbox oil.

And here, at the back, we
actually have a wet clutch.
It looks like this.

It's very tiny, because
it's space-limited.

And due to the fact that it's
small in diameter, we did a

lot of disks to get the desired
force of locking when
we use the clutch.

So if you look here, you can
spin this shaft here.
You have 11 disks here.

And if I put just a little bit
of pressure here with my

finger, I can't spin
it at all.

And if I release,
I can spin it.

And here, we put several hundred
kilos of pressure when
we activate the clutch.

Now what this does, it's sitting
in here, when we

shift, when we open the main
clutch, at the same time as

that happens, we lock the input
shaft at the end of the

input shaft with this hydraulic
clutch or, slash,

brake-- hydraulic brake, it
could also be called--

to instantly drop the
speed drastically
of the input shaft.

So when we're shifting gears, we
don't have to wait for the

synchros to equalize the speed
between the gears.

That has already happened with
the help of this wet clutch.

So basically, we're getting an
AMT, an Automated Manual

Transmission with synchros
to act as fast as
if it had dog rings.

We basically have zero
synchronization time.

We only have clutch time,
not clutch time and then
synchronization time.

It's already pre-synchronized
with this wet clutch.

Now this is something quite
revolutionary, because it

means that we can have shift
times that are so minute that

it doesn't really make sense to
have a dual clutch gearbox

with much more complexity,
weight.

And therefore, it's not possible
to have the same

torque capability within the
same weight and space
constraint as this gearbox.

So it's basically taking an AMT
technology to the limit,

making it shift as fast as a dog
ring gearbox, drastically

reducing the torque-to-torque
time it takes to shift, but

not sacrificing weight, space,
and normal driveability.

So we really like
this solution.

And the weight of this
gearbox is 81 kilos.

And it's, by far, the lightest
hypercar gearbox we've ever
seen or heard of.

And yeah, we're quite happy that
we have managed in-house

with our small engineering team
to take it to the next

level with these items to make
it the state-of-the-art

gearbox there is today
for a hypercar.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

title: Putting 1140 hp to the Ground - /Inside Koenigsegg
